Developer Guides

zkSNARKs and PLONK

Overview

zkSNARKs are powerful modern cryptography primitives used to prove the correct execution of an arbitrary computation without the need for a verifier to re-execute that computation. In addition to that, zkSNARKs have the ability to reveal only some parts of the computation and retain the rest as a secret, all while proving correctness of 100% of it.

Common use cases for zkSNARKs in modern blockchains are:

  • proving the correct execution of a smartcontract endpoint without requiring all validators in the network to re-execute the corresponding transaction,
  • implementing privacy-preserving protocols such as anonymous voting and payments.

The acronym "zkSNARK" stands for Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-interactive Argument of Knowledge:

  • zero-knowledge means the proven computation is not revealed, except for the parts the prover chooses to reveal;
  • succinct means the size of the proof is sublinear in the size of the original computation (in fact, the zkSNARK scheme used in Libernet results in constant-size proofs of about 1 KiB each);
  • non-interactive means the verification protocol does not require a challenge-response roundtrip;
  • argument of knowledge indicates that the prover really had the full trace of the computation, notwithstanding the above requirements.

Libernet uses zkSNARKs in a few different contexts, for example anonymous payments towards incognito accounts. Our zkSNARK protocol is based on KZG polynomial commitments over the BLS12-381 elliptic curve, and PLONK arithmetization. It uses the Poseidon algebraic hash for hashing.

This page describes the full PLONK protocol that we use in Libernet in detail, but it assumes knowledge of KZG. Be sure to understand everything in Dankrad Feist's article before moving on.

Circuits

In the zkSNARK world a computation is conceptually rendered as a circuit with gates and wires. The gates represent basic arithmetic operations such as addition and multiplication, and the wires connect the inputs and outputs of the gates.

As an example, consider the following circuit:

It's easy to see how this encodes the computation of x3+x+5x^3 + x + 5x3+x+5. A prover with this circuit can produce a zkSNARK proof that convinces a verifier of a statement like "I have a secret number xxx such that x3+x+5=35x^3 + x + 5 = 35x3+x+5=35", without revealing xxx. This is a simple example so it's easy to find out that the number would be x=3x = 3x=3, but zkSNARKs enable complex protocols such as anonymous voting and payments where some elements of the computation remain secret.

Evaluation Domain and Polynomial Interpolation

Libernet uses the BLS12-381 elliptic curve, so all of its zkSNARK circuits are evaluated on the scalar field of that curve. The field has the following ~256 bit order:

r = 0x73eda753299d7d483339d80809a1d80553bda402fffe5bfeffffffff00000001

So the values carried by the wires of our circuits are ~256 bit integers.

In zkSNARKs we encode all computation in polynomials. To see how a polynomial can encode an ordered list of integers, consider the following list of pairs:

(0, 33)
(1, 10)
(2, 24)
(3, 49)

To encode the ordered list of integers [33, 10, 24, 49] we can use a polynomial that crosses the points represented by the above pairs. This is achieved by polynomial interpolation, and the resulting polynomial would evaluate to 33 in 0, to 10 in 1, etc., effectively encoding the original list at the coordinates 0, 1, 2, and 3.

There are two distinct approaches to implementing polynomial interpolation: Lagrange interpolation and the Fast Fourier Transform. Algorithms based on Lagrange interpolation take O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2) time where NNN is the number of points to interpolate, so in Libernet we use the Fast Fourier Transform which takes O(N⋅log(N))O(N \cdot log(N))O(N⋅log(N)) time. However, some parts of our PLONK protocol also use Lagrange basis polynomials for other purposes (more on that later).

The Fast Fourier Transform algorithm is significantly faster than Lagrange interpolation but has two important restrictions:

  • the number of interpolated points must be a power of 2,
  • and the X coordinates of the points cannot have arbitrary values, they must be powers of an N-th root of unity.

As a quick refresher, an NNN-th root of unity is a number ω\omegaω such that ωN=1\omega^N = 1ωN=1. The FFT algorithm requires the X-coordinates of the interpolated points to be:

ω0,ω1,ω2,...,ωN−1\omega^0, \omega^1, \omega^2, ..., \omega^{N - 1}ω0,ω1,ω2,...,ωN−1

where NNN is a power of 2.

When working with standard math tools the ωN=1\omega^N = 1ωN=1 equation has exactly NNN complex solutions. For example, for N=4N = 4N=4 the four solutions are iii, −i-i−i, 111, and −1-1−1 (with iii being the imaginary unit −1\sqrt{-1}−1​).

In modular arithmetic things work differently, but since the BL12-381 scalar field has prime order, Fermat's Little Theorem shows us that the ωN=1\omega^N = 1ωN=1 equation can still be satisfied. In fact, the field has the following well-known 2322^{32}232-th root of unity:

0x16a2a19edfe81f20d09b681922c813b4b63683508c2280b93829971f439f0d2b

There are 2322^{32}232 different powers of this number, allowing us to interpolate at most 2322^{32}232 (or 4,294,967,296) points using the Fast Fourier Transform. From there we can adapt the FFT algorithm to run on any number of points kkk that's a power of two less than or equal to 2322^{32}232.

Let's define:

k=2h,0<h≤32k = 2^h, 0 < h \leq 32k=2h,0<h≤32

We can obtain a kkk-th root of unity ω0\omega_0ω0​ from the NNN-th root of unity ω\omegaω as follows:

ω0=ω232−h\omega_0 = \omega^{2^{32-h}}ω0​=ω232−h

In fact:

ω0k=(ω232−h)k=ω232−h⋅2h=ω232−h+h=ω232=1\omega_0^k = (\omega^{2^{32 - h}})^k = \omega^{2^{32 - h} \cdot 2^h} = \omega^{2^{32 - h + h}} = \omega^{2^{32}} = 1ω0k​=(ω232−h)k=ω232−h⋅2h=ω232−h+h=ω232=1

Given all the above, we'll often work with powers of ω0\omega_0ω0​ rather than plain naturals as our evaluation domain. Instead of encoding the following points:

(0, 33)
(1, 10)
(2, 24)
(3, 49)

we'll use the FFT algorithm to encode the following points:

(w0^0, 33)
(w0^1, 10)
(w0^2, 24)
(w0^3, 49)

where w0 is a kkk-th root of unity ω0\omega_0ω0​, in this case k=4k = 4k=4.

Note

In the following we will use ω\omegaω instead of ω0\omega_0ω0​ for notational simplicity. We still use kkk to indicate the (padded) size of the circuit, so you'll often see things like ωk−1\omega^{k - 1}ωk−1.

The Fast Fourier Transform and other algorithms on polynomials are implemented in the poly module of our crypto library.

Witnesses and Constraints

Proving the correct execution of an arbitrary computation takes the following steps:

  1. both the prover and the verifier become aware of the same circuit (gates and wires);
  2. the prover runs the computation, providing input values to the circuit, computing all intermediate values, and obtaining the output values;
  3. the prover provides:
    • a proof of knowledge of the above values;
    • a proof that the above values satisfy certain constraints;
  4. the verifier verifies the above proofs without any challenge-response roundtrip, just checking them against the original circuit.

The set of values produced at step #2 is known as the witness. You can think of it as the "execution trace" of the computation, since it includes all intermediate values. In the PLONK proving scheme the witness is organized in three columns of equal height:

  • the column of the left-hand side inputs of all gates,
  • the column of the right-hand side inputs of all gates,
  • and the column of the outputs of all gates.

The i-th row of each column contains the corresponding value for the i-th gate.

For example, the circuit above would have the following witness when the secret input xxx is set to 3:

LHSRHSOut
339
9327
32730
30535

Proving knowledge of the witness (as per point 3a above) is easy:

  • the columns of the witness are padded with zeros until their size is a power of 2,
  • each column is then encoded as a polynomial using the FFT algorithm,
  • the polynomial is committed to G1 as per KZG and the 3 commitments are provided as proof,
  • KZG openings are provided to reveal the public parts of the computation.

However, this doesn't prove that the witnessed values really did result from computing the known circuit. To achieve that we need to enforce a set of polynomial equations that characterize the circuit. These equations are known as constraints. The initial definition of a circuit, which is performed only once and ahead of time, results in two types of constraints: gate constraints and wire constraints, discussed below. The prover and the verifier can perform this initial definition process independently, but it must results in exactly the same constraints for the proofs to be valid.

Gate Constraints

In the PLONK proving scheme each gate defines a polynomial constraint of the following form:

qL⋅l+qR⋅r+qO⋅o+qM⋅l⋅r+qC=0q_L \cdot l + q_R \cdot r + q_O \cdot o + q_M \cdot l \cdot r + q_C = 0qL​⋅l+qR​⋅r+qO​⋅o+qM​⋅l⋅r+qC​=0

where:

  • lll is the left-hand side input of the gate,
  • rrr is the right-hand side input of the gate,
  • ooo is the output of the gate,
  • the q∗q_*q∗​ factors are constants specific to the gate.

For example, an addition gate would have:

qL=1,qR=1,qO=−1,qM=0,qC=0q_L = 1, q_R = 1, q_O = -1, q_M = 0, q_C = 0qL​=1,qR​=1,qO​=−1,qM​=0,qC​=0

effectively yielding the constraint:

l+r−o=0l+r=o\begin{aligned} l + r - o = 0 \\ l + r = o \end{aligned}l+r−o=0l+r=o​

A multiplication gate would instead have:

qL=0,qR=0,qO=−1,qM=1,qC=0q_L = 0, q_R = 0, q_O = -1, q_M = 1, q_C = 0qL​=0,qR​=0,qO​=−1,qM​=1,qC​=0

resulting in:

−o+l⋅r=0l⋅r=o\begin{aligned} -o + l \cdot r = 0 \\ l \cdot r = o \end{aligned}−o+l⋅r=0l⋅r=o​

Note

Negative values don't exist in our scalar field. What we actually do for the above gate types to achieve the same result is to set qO=r−1q_O = r - 1qO​=r−1, to which -1 is congruent. rrr is the prime order of the BLS12-381 scalar field, provided above.

Defining a circuit with NNN gates would result in NNN values for qLq_LqL​, NNN values for qRq_RqR​, and so on, meaning we can encode the five q∗q_*q∗​ columns in five corresponding polynomials Q∗Q_*Q∗​. Let LLL, RRR, and OOO be the polynomials encoding the three witness columns. After interpolating all polynomials we have:

T(x)=QL(x)⋅L(x)+QR(x)⋅R(x)+QO(x)⋅O(x)+QM(x)⋅L(x)⋅R(x)+QC(x)T(x) = Q_L(x) \cdot L(x) + Q_R(x) \cdot R(x) + Q_O(x) \cdot O(x) + Q_M(x) \cdot L(x) \cdot R(x) + Q_C(x)T(x)=QL​(x)⋅L(x)+QR​(x)⋅R(x)+QO​(x)⋅O(x)+QM​(x)⋅L(x)⋅R(x)+QC​(x)

Note that the Q∗Q_*Q∗​ can (and in fact must) be interpolated ahead of time, so they only contribute to the cost of the setup phase (in both the prover and the verifier) but not to the proving or verification cost.

This equation is a single polynomial equation that we can commit to and for which we can provide KZG openings on one or more challenge points. To maintain the protocol non-interactive we can use the Fiat-Shamir heuristic to determine the challenge points, e.g. we can compute them by hashing the polynomial commitments of the witness columns.

To prove that the witness (L,R,O)(L, R, O)(L,R,O) really was computed by the circuit gates defined by Q∗Q_*Q∗​ we need to prove:

T(ωi)=0T(\omega^i) = 0T(ωi)=0

for all iii, meaning that our constraint equation must be zero on all points of the evaluation domain ω0\omega^0ω0, ω1\omega^1ω1, ω2\omega^2ω2, ..., ωk−1\omega^{k - 1}ωk−1. In other words, all powers of ω\omegaω must be roots of the polynomial T(x)T(x)T(x). That means TTT can be rewritten as:

T(x)=P(x)⋅(x−ω0)⋅(x−ω1)⋅...⋅(x−ωk−1)=P(x)⋅∏i=0k−1(x−ωi)\begin{aligned} T(x) &= P(x) \cdot (x - \omega^0) \cdot (x - \omega^1) \cdot ... \cdot (x - \omega^{k - 1}) \\ &= P(x) \cdot \prod_{i = 0}^{k - 1} (x - \omega^i) \end{aligned}T(x)​=P(x)⋅(x−ω0)⋅(x−ω1)⋅...⋅(x−ωk−1)=P(x)⋅i=0∏k−1​(x−ωi)​

where PPP is a quotient polynomial resulting from the division of TTT by ∏i=0k−1(x−ωi)\prod_{i = 0}^{k - 1} (x - \omega^i)∏i=0k−1​(x−ωi).

The divisor ∏i=0k−1(x−ωi)\prod_{i = 0}^{k - 1} (x - \omega^i)∏i=0k−1​(x−ωi) is a polynomial that vanishes on all the evaluation domain and doesn't have any other roots. It's sometimes known as the zero polynomial, and we'll indicate it with H(x)H(x)H(x).

We also use the following notation:

T(x)≡0mod  HT(x) \equiv 0 \mod HT(x)≡0modH

meaning that the polynomial division of TTT by HHH yields a zero remainder.

Determining the coefficients of HHH is very straightforward because the condition of vanishing on all kkk-th roots of unity is simply defined by the equation:

xk=1xk−1=0\begin{aligned} x^k = 1 \\ x^k - 1 = 0 \end{aligned}xk=1xk−1=0​

so we have:

H(x)=xk−1H(x) = x^k - 1H(x)=xk−1

Circling back to the problem of proving that T(x)T(x)T(x) is satisfied, i.e. zero on all powers of ω\omegaω, we can adopt the following protocol:

  • the prover determines a challenge value ξ\xiξ using the Fiat-Shamir heuristic;
  • the prover generates the coefficients of TTT by multiplying the Q∗Q_*Q∗​ polynomials by the witness polynomials as per the definition of TTT;
  • the prover divides TTT by HHH using polynomial long division and obtains PPP (if TTT really is satisfied there must be no remainder);
  • the prover commits to PPP and opens it at ξ\xiξ.

Note that the existence of PPP without any remainder implies that TTT is divisible by HHH and is therefore zero on all the domain and fully satisfied. Thanks to that, on the verifier side we just need to verify the KZG openings for L(ξ)L(\xi)L(ξ), R(ξ)R(\xi)R(ξ), O(ξ)O(\xi)O(ξ), and P(ξ)P(\xi)P(ξ) and check:

QL(ξ)⋅L(ξ)+QR(ξ)⋅R(ξ)+QO(ξ)⋅O(ξ)+QM(ξ)⋅L(ξ)⋅R(ξ)+QC(ξ)=P(ξ)⋅H(ξ)Q_L(\xi) \cdot L(\xi) + Q_R(\xi) \cdot R(\xi) + Q_O(\xi) \cdot O(\xi) + Q_M(\xi) \cdot L(\xi) \cdot R(\xi) + Q_C(\xi) = P(\xi) \cdot H(\xi)QL​(ξ)⋅L(ξ)+QR​(ξ)⋅R(ξ)+QO​(ξ)⋅O(ξ)+QM​(ξ)⋅L(ξ)⋅R(ξ)+QC​(ξ)=P(ξ)⋅H(ξ)

This is however not yet enough to prove that the witness really fits the circuit: our protocol so far checks that each gate has worked correctly but doesn't check that the gates were connected as intended. To achieve the latter we need to check wire constraints.

Wire Constraints

This is the most complex part of PLONK.

Proving that the gates of the circuit are connected as intended boils down to proving that specific groups of cells of the witness table have equal values, without revealing the whole witness.

Here is once again the full witness table of our sample circuit:

LHSRHSOut
339
9327
32730
30535

Based on the wiring of the circuit, we need to partition the wires as follows and prove that each partition contains identical values. We use LiL_iLi​, RiR_iRi​, and OiO_iOi​ to indicate the iii-th row of the left input, right input, and output column, respectively.

  • {L0,R0,R1,L2}\{ L_0, R_0, R_1, L_2 \}{L0​,R0​,R1​,L2​} (value 3)
  • {O0,L1}\{ O_0, L_1 \}{O0​,L1​} (value 9)
  • {O1,R2}\{ O_1, R_2 \}{O1​,R2​} (value 27)
  • {O2,L3}\{ O_2, L_3 \}{O2​,L3​} (value 30)
  • {R3}\{ R_3 \}{R3​} (value 5)
  • {O3}\{ O_3 \}{O3​} (value 35)

The core insight is that the witness wouldn't change if we permuted the elements of each partition arbitrarily, because they have identical values. Therefore, to achieve our goal we'll build a polynomial expression based on permutations of the X coordinates of our domain, ω0,ω1,...,ωk−1\omega^0, \omega^1, ..., \omega^{k - 1}ω0,ω1,...,ωk−1.

Let's first analyze a simplified case that works on a single witness column polynomial WWW. Let σ\sigmaσ be a permutation of the evaluation domain that rotates or otherwise rearranges the coordinates of each wire partition, and let σi\sigma_iσi​ be the iii-th element of the permutation. Let β\betaβ and γ\gammaγ be two challenge values computed with Fiat-Shamir (not the same as the ξ\xiξ challenge used for gate constraints). We define the coordinate pair accumulator of WWW as follows:

∏i=0k−1W(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γW(ωi)+β⋅σi+γ\prod_{i = 0}^{k - 1} \frac{W(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{W(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_i + \gamma}i=0∏k−1​W(ωi)+β⋅σi​+γW(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γ​

This gives us an intuition of how partition-wise wire equality is proven: since the σi\sigma_iσi​ coordinates in the denominator are permuted, the value of the coordinate pair accumulator is 1 iff the factors in the denominator remain equal to those in the numerator except for their order -- in other words, iff the permutation didn't change anything in the overall expression. So proving that all wire constraints are satisfied reduces to proving that the coordinate pair accumulator product equals 1 for that witness.

Let's now extend this technique to work with three different witness columns LLL, RRR, and OOO. We will build a "unified" coordinate pair accumulator multiplying the individual accumulators of the three columns together, but to avoid collisions among the X coordinates we need to introduce two constants k1k_1k1​ and k2k_2k2​ in the accumulators of RRR and OOO respectively (we can use 1 as the constant for LLL) and we need to change the construction of σ\sigmaσ accordingly. In Libernet we set k1=71k_1 = 71k1​=71 and k2=104k_2 = 104k2​=104.

Specifically, we will now construct three separate permutations σL\sigma_LσL​, σR\sigma_RσR​, and σO\sigma_OσO​. To do that, we first lay out the X coordinates of LLL, RRR, and OOO in a single array with length 3k3k3k (note that the coordinates of RRR and OOO are multiplied by k1k_1k1​ and k2k_2k2​ respectively, so all values are different):

ω0,ω1,...,ωk−1,k1ω0,k1ω1,...,k1ωk−1,k2ω0,k2ω1,...,k2ωk−1\omega^0, \omega^1, ..., \omega^{k - 1}, k_1 \omega^0, k_1 \omega^1, ..., k_1 \omega^{k - 1}, k_2 \omega^0, k_2 \omega^1, ..., k_2 \omega^{k - 1}ω0,ω1,...,ωk−1,k1​ω0,k1​ω1,...,k1​ωk−1,k2​ω0,k2​ω1,...,k2​ωk−1

Then we rotate or otherwise rearrange the elements of each partition. It's okay to use a predefined permutation algorithm, e.g. rotation by a fixed offset; the only requirement is that each partition has a permutation with exactly 1 cycle. For example, if we used a rotation by 1 slot of our sample circuit above we'd get the following permutation:

resulting in:

ω2,k2ω0,k1ω1,k2ω2,ω0,k1ω0,k2ω1,k1ω3,ω1,k1ω2,ω3,k2ω3\omega^2, k_2 \omega^0, k_1 \omega^1, k_2 \omega^2, \omega^0, k_1 \omega^0, k_2 \omega^1, k_1 \omega^3, \omega^1, k_1 \omega^2, \omega^3, k_2 \omega^3ω2,k2​ω0,k1​ω1,k2​ω2,ω0,k1​ω0,k2​ω1,k1​ω3,ω1,k1​ω2,ω3,k2​ω3

Once we have this permuted, 3k3k3k-long sequence, we get:

  • σL\sigma_LσL​ by taking the first kkk elements,
  • σR\sigma_RσR​ by taking the next kkk elements,
  • σO\sigma_OσO​ by taking the last kkk elements.

In our example we'd get:

σL={ω2,k2ω0,k1ω1,k2ω2}σR={ω0,k1ω0,k2ω1,k1ω3}σO={ω1,k1ω2,ω3,k2ω3}\begin{aligned} \sigma_L &= \{ \omega^2, k_2 \omega^0, k_1 \omega^1, k_2 \omega^2 \} \\ \sigma_R &= \{ \omega^0, k_1 \omega^0, k_2 \omega^1, k_1 \omega^3 \} \\ \sigma_O &= \{ \omega^1, k_1 \omega^2, \omega^3, k_2 \omega^3 \} \\ \end{aligned}σL​σR​σO​​={ω2,k2​ω0,k1​ω1,k2​ω2}={ω0,k1​ω0,k2​ω1,k1​ω3}={ω1,k1​ω2,ω3,k2​ω3}​

These three σ∗\sigma_*σ∗​ sequences can be encoded in three polynomials, each mapping an element of the evaluation domain to the corresponding permuted element. Following our example, the σL\sigma_LσL​ polynomial is obtained by interpolating the following points:

(w^0, w^2)
(w^1, k2 * w^0)
(w^2, k1 * w^1)
(w^3, k2 * w^2)

For σR\sigma_RσR​ we have:

(w^0, w^0)
(w^1, k1 * w^0)
(w^2, k2 * w^1)
(w^3, k1 * w^3)

And for σO\sigma_OσO​:

(w^0, w^1)
(w^1, k1 * w^2)
(w^2, w^3)
(w^3, k2 * w^3)

Much like the Q∗Q_*Q∗​ polynomials from the gate constraints, the σ∗\sigma_*σ∗​ polynomials of the wire constraints are also interpolated only once ahead of time, and do not contribute to the proving or verification cost.

The final coordinate pair accumulator expression for three witness columns is:

∏i=0k−1L(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γL(ωi)+β⋅σL(ωi)+γ⋅R(ωi)+β⋅k1⋅ωi+γR(ωi)+β⋅σR(ωi)+γ⋅O(ωi)+β⋅k2⋅ωi+γO(ωi)+β⋅σO(ωi)+γ\prod_{i = 0}^{k - 1} \frac{L(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{L(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_L(\omega^i) + \gamma} \cdot \frac{R(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot k_1 \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{R(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_R(\omega^i) + \gamma} \cdot \frac{O(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot k_2 \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{O(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_O(\omega^i) + \gamma}i=0∏k−1​L(ωi)+β⋅σL​(ωi)+γL(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γ​⋅R(ωi)+β⋅σR​(ωi)+γR(ωi)+β⋅k1​⋅ωi+γ​⋅O(ωi)+β⋅σO​(ωi)+γO(ωi)+β⋅k2​⋅ωi+γ​

As mentioned above, we need to prove that this expression equals 1 when plugging the polynomials of the proven witness, LLL, RRR, and OOO. The KZG commitment scheme doesn't provide any means to prove this value directly, so we'll use a technique based on the following recursive definition of the coordinate pair accumulator:

Z(ω0)=1Z(ωi+1)=Z(ωi)⋅L(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γL(ωi)+β⋅σL(ωi)+γ⋅R(ωi)+β⋅k1⋅ωi+γR(ωi)+β⋅σR(ωi)+γ⋅O(ωi)+β⋅k2⋅ωi+γO(ωi)+β⋅σO(ωi)+γ\begin{aligned} Z(\omega^0) &= 1 \\ Z(\omega^{i + 1}) &= Z(\omega^i) \cdot \frac{L(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{L(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_L(\omega^i) + \gamma} \cdot \frac{R(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot k_1 \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{R(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_R(\omega^i) + \gamma} \cdot \frac{O(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot k_2 \cdot \omega^i + \gamma}{O(\omega^i) + \beta \cdot \sigma_O(\omega^i) + \gamma} \end{aligned}Z(ω0)Z(ωi+1)​=1=Z(ωi)⋅L(ωi)+β⋅σL​(ωi)+γL(ωi)+β⋅ωi+γ​⋅R(ωi)+β⋅σR​(ωi)+γR(ωi)+β⋅k1​⋅ωi+γ​⋅O(ωi)+β⋅σO​(ωi)+γO(ωi)+β⋅k2​⋅ωi+γ​​

Let NNN be the polynomial of the numerator and DDD the polynomial of the denominator:

N(x)=(L(x)+β⋅x+γ)⋅(R(x)+β⋅k1⋅x+γ)⋅(O(x)+β⋅k2⋅x+γ)D(x)=(L(x)+β⋅σL(x)+γ)⋅(R(x)+β⋅σR(x)+γ)⋅(O(x)+β⋅σO(x)+γ)\begin{aligned} N(x) &= (L(x) + \beta \cdot x + \gamma) \cdot (R(x) + \beta \cdot k_1 \cdot x + \gamma) \cdot (O(x) + \beta \cdot k_2 \cdot x + \gamma) \\ D(x) &= (L(x) + \beta \cdot \sigma_L(x) + \gamma) \cdot (R(x) + \beta \cdot \sigma_R(x) + \gamma) \cdot (O(x) + \beta \cdot \sigma_O(x) + \gamma) \end{aligned}N(x)D(x)​=(L(x)+β⋅x+γ)⋅(R(x)+β⋅k1​⋅x+γ)⋅(O(x)+β⋅k2​⋅x+γ)=(L(x)+β⋅σL​(x)+γ)⋅(R(x)+β⋅σR​(x)+γ)⋅(O(x)+β⋅σO​(x)+γ)​

The inductive case becomes:

Z(ωi+1)=Z(ωi)⋅N(ωi)D(ωi)Z(\omega^{i + 1}) = Z(\omega^i) \cdot \frac{N(\omega^i)}{D(\omega^i)}Z(ωi+1)=Z(ωi)⋅D(ωi)N(ωi)​ Z(ωi+1)⋅D(ωi)=Z(ωi)⋅N(ωi)Z(\omega^{i + 1}) \cdot D(\omega^i) = Z(\omega^i) \cdot N(\omega^i)Z(ωi+1)⋅D(ωi)=Z(ωi)⋅N(ωi) Z(ωi+1)⋅D(ωi)−Z(ωi)⋅N(ωi)=0Z(\omega^{i + 1}) \cdot D(\omega^i) - Z(\omega^i) \cdot N(\omega^i) = 0Z(ωi+1)⋅D(ωi)−Z(ωi)⋅N(ωi)=0

The last formula is equivalent to:

Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0mod  HZ(\omega x) D(x) - Z(x) N(x) \equiv 0 \mod{H}Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0modH

The problem of proving the wire constraints has now been turned into proving the two following claims:

  • base case: Z(1)=1Z(1) = 1Z(1)=1
  • inductive case: Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0mod  HZ(\omega x) D(x) - Z(x) N(x) \equiv 0 \mod{H}Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0modH

Note what happens after the last element of the domain, ωk−1\omega^{k - 1}ωk−1:

Z(ωk)=N(ωk−1)D(ωk−1)⋅N(ωk−2)D(ωk−2)⋅...Z(\omega^k) = \frac{N(\omega^{k - 1})}{D(\omega^{k - 1})} \cdot \frac{N(\omega^{k - 2})}{D(\omega^{k - 2})} \cdot ...Z(ωk)=D(ωk−1)N(ωk−1)​⋅D(ωk−2)N(ωk−2)​⋅...

but ω\omegaω is a kkk-th root of unity, so Z(ωk)=Z(1)=1Z(\omega^k) = Z(1) = 1Z(ωk)=Z(1)=1. So together, the base case and the inductive cases ultimately prove that the coordinate pair accumulator product equals 1, meaning the wire constraints are fully satisfied.

In principle, proving the base case is very straightforward as we simply need to commit to ZZZ and open it at 111. However, for reasons that are explained in the next section, it's best to convert this part of the proof to another equation in the form P(x)≡0mod  HP(x) \equiv 0 \mod HP(x)≡0modH. We achieve that using the Lagrange basis polynomial L0L_0L0​ that activates on the first element of the evaluation domain ω0\omega^0ω0 and vanishes on all others:

L0(ω0)=1L0(ωi)=0,∀i>0\begin{aligned} L_0(\omega^0) &= 1 \\ L_0(\omega^i) &= 0, \forall i > 0 \end{aligned}L0​(ω0)L0​(ωi)​=1=0,∀i>0​

The definition of L0L_0L0​ is:

L0(x)=∏i=1k−1x−ωiω0−ωi=∏i=1k−1x−ωi1−ωiL_0(x) = \prod_{i = 1}^{k - 1} \frac{x - \omega^i}{\omega^0 - \omega^i} = \prod_{i = 1}^{k - 1} \frac{x - \omega^i}{1 - \omega^i}L0​(x)=i=1∏k−1​ω0−ωix−ωi​=i=1∏k−1​1−ωix−ωi​

The numerator is equivalent to all linear factors of HHH except (x−ω0)(x - \omega^0)(x−ω0):

∏i=1k−1(x−ωi)=H(x)x−ω0=xk−1x−1\prod_{i = 1}^{k - 1} (x - \omega^i) = \frac{H(x)}{x - \omega^0} = \frac{x^k - 1}{x - 1}i=1∏k−1​(x−ωi)=x−ω0H(x)​=x−1xk−1​

Let's call that H0H_0H0​. The denominator is equivalent to evaluating H0H_0H0​ in 111, which unfortunately yields an indeterminate form if we do it using the above closed form:

H0(x)=xk−1x−1H_0(x) = \frac{x^k - 1}{x - 1}H0​(x)=x−1xk−1​ H0(1)=1k−11−1=00H_0(1) = \frac{1^k - 1}{1 - 1} = \frac00H0​(1)=1−11k−1​=00​

But we can still find what it converges to using L'Hopital's rule:

lim⁡x→1xk−1x−1=lim⁡x→1kxk−11=k\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^k - 1}{x - 1} = \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{kx^{k - 1}}{1} = kx→1lim​x−1xk−1​=x→1lim​1kxk−1​=k

Since H0H_0H0​ is a polynomial it's continuous across the whole domain, so the limit we found is the actual value of the polynomial in 111 and the indeterminate form was just an artifact of the closed form.

Knowing the numerator and the denominator, the ratio between the two becomes:

L0(x)=xk−1k⋅(x−1)L_0(x) = \frac{x^k - 1}{k \cdot (x - 1)}L0​(x)=k⋅(x−1)xk−1​

Once we have L0L_0L0​, proving Z(1)=1Z(1) = 1Z(1)=1 is also straightforward. The constraint becomes:

(Z(x)−1)⋅L0(x)≡0mod  H(Z(x) - 1) \cdot L_0(x) \equiv 0 \mod H(Z(x)−1)⋅L0​(x)≡0modH

The left-hand side vanishes everywhere because either L0L_0L0​ is 0 or Z(x)Z(x)Z(x) is 1.

Putting It All Together

Throughout the previous sections the problem of proving the correct execution of an arbitrary computation represented as a PLONK circuit has been reduced to proving these four pieces:

  1. committing to the witness polynomials LLL, RRR, and OOO and providing KZG openings for the public parts;

  2. proving the gate constraint:

QL(x)L(x)+QR(x)R(x)+QO(x)O(x)+QM(x)L(x)R(x)+QC(x)≡0mod  HQ_L(x)L(x) + Q_R(x)R(x) + Q_O(x)O(x) + Q_M(x)L(x)R(x) + Q_C(x) \equiv 0 \mod HQL​(x)L(x)+QR​(x)R(x)+QO​(x)O(x)+QM​(x)L(x)R(x)+QC​(x)≡0modH
  1. proving the base case of the wire constraint:
(Z(x)−1)⋅L0(x)≡0mod  H(Z(x) - 1) \cdot L_0(x) \equiv 0 \mod H(Z(x)−1)⋅L0​(x)≡0modH
  1. proving the inductive case of the wire constraint:
Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0mod  HZ(\omega x)D(x) - Z(x)N(x) \equiv 0 \mod HZ(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)≡0modH

The equations at #2, #3, and #4 represent polynomial expressions that must vanish on all powers of ω\omegaω. Let TGT_GTG​, TW0T_{W_0}TW0​​, and TWT_WTW​ be those expressions:

  • gate constraint:
TG(x)=QL(x)L(x)+QR(x)R(x)+QO(x)O(x)+QM(x)L(x)R(x)+QC(x)T_G(x) = Q_L(x)L(x) + Q_R(x)R(x) + Q_O(x)O(x) + Q_M(x)L(x)R(x) + Q_C(x)TG​(x)=QL​(x)L(x)+QR​(x)R(x)+QO​(x)O(x)+QM​(x)L(x)R(x)+QC​(x)
  • wire constraint base case:
TW0(x)=(Z(x)−1)⋅L0(x)T_{W_0}(x) = (Z(x) - 1) \cdot L_0(x)TW0​​(x)=(Z(x)−1)⋅L0​(x)
  • wire constraint inductive case:
TW(x)=Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)T_W(x) = Z(\omega x)D(x) - Z(x)N(x)TW​(x)=Z(ωx)D(x)−Z(x)N(x)

We have already mentioned a technique to prove our T∗(x)≡0mod  HT_*(x) \equiv 0 \mod HT∗​(x)≡0modH equations using KZG:

  • use polynomial long division to find the corresponding quotient P∗P_*P∗​ such that T∗(x)=H(x)⋅P∗(x)T_*(x) = H(x) \cdot P_*(x)T∗​(x)=H(x)⋅P∗​(x) (i.e. no remainder),
  • send the KZG commitments to T∗T_*T∗​ and P∗P_*P∗​,
  • open the commitments in a Fiat-Shamir challenge ξ\xiξ,
  • check that T∗(ξ)=H(ξ)⋅P∗(ξ)T_*(\xi) = H(\xi) \cdot P_*(\xi)T∗​(ξ)=H(ξ)⋅P∗​(ξ).

While proving TGT_GTG​, TW0T_{W_0}TW0​​, and TWT_WTW​ separately with this technique would work correctly, we can achieve higher efficiency by proving them together in a single equation. A naive approach would consist of adding the three constraints up:

TG(x)+TW0(x)+TW(x)≡0mod  HT_G(x) + T_{W_0}(x) + T_W(x) \equiv 0 \mod HTG​(x)+TW0​​(x)+TW​(x)≡0modH

However that doesn't prove each expression vanishes, it only proves their sum vanishes, exposing us to cancellation attacks. A malicious prover might be able to satisfy the constraint by building a bad witness such that TG(x)=42T_G(x) = 42TG​(x)=42 and TW0(x)+TW(x)=−42T_{W_0}(x) + T_W(x) = -42TW0​​(x)+TW​(x)=−42. To counter that we need to use a new Fiat-Shamir challenge α\alphaα and combine our T∗T_*T∗​ with powers of α\alphaα:

TG(x)+αTW0(x)+α2TW(x)≡0mod  HT_G(x) + \alpha T_{W_0}(x) + \alpha^2 T_W(x) \equiv 0 \mod HTG​(x)+αTW0​​(x)+α2TW​(x)≡0modH

The Fiat-Shamir heuristic here prevents the malicious prover of the above example from crafting a bad witness because they'd have to know α\alphaα, which is a hash of the witness itself.

So our proving protocol has now been simplified to:

  1. committing to the witness polynomials LLL, RRR, and OOO and providing KZG openings for the public parts,
  2. proving a single constraint T(x)≡0mod  HT(x) \equiv 0 \mod HT(x)≡0modH,

where T(x)=TG(x)+αTW0(x)+α2TW(x)T(x) = T_G(x) + \alpha T_{W_0}(x) + \alpha^2 T_W(x)T(x)=TG​(x)+αTW0​​(x)+α2TW​(x).

The Full Protocol

This section specifies the details of the PLONK protocol used in Libernet. It's organized in three phases:

  • a setup phase that runs ahead of time and prepares the circuit describing the computation to prove;
  • a proving phase where a prover runs the computations, produces the corresponding witness, and provides a zkSNARK proof of correctness;
  • and a verification phase where a verifier validates the above zkSNARK proof.

For hashing we use the Poseidon algebraic hash function over the scalar field of BLS12-381 with x5x^5x5 S-box and T=3 (rate=2, capacity=1).
